body:
Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook says his company had no choice but to file a lawsuit against Qualcomm (QCOM) because the mobile chipmaker was overstepping its legal bounds.

On his earnings conference call with analysts late Tuesday, Cook discussed why Apple is taking its supplier to court.

"I don't like litigation and view it as a last resort," Cook said. "And so you should take from our filing that we viewed it as we didn't see another way forward."

Apple filed a lawsuit against Qualcomm in U.S. federal district court on Jan. 20, alleging that Qualcomm demanded onerous terms for its technology and sought to punish Apple for cooperating in a government antitrust probe.

Apple said Qualcomm has withheld $1 billion in rebate payments to Apple as retribution for the iPhone maker's participation in an investigation by South Korea's antitrust regulator.

"They were insisting on charging royalties for technologies that they had nothing to do with," Cook said. "And so we were in a situation where the more we innovated with unique features like Touch ID or advanced displays or cameras, just to name a few, the more money Qualcomm would collect for no reason and the more expensive it would be therefore for us to innovate."

Cook drew an analogy to reinforce his point.

"It's somewhat like buying a sofa, and you charge somebody a different price depending upon the price of the house that it goes into," Cook said. "This doesn't make sense, and we don't believe it will pass muster in the courts."

Apple's lawsuit was filed three days after the U.S. Federal Trade Commission sued Qualcomm and accused it of using anticompetitive tactics to maintain its monopoly in baseband processors used in wireless devices.

Apple also has filed legal action against Qualcomm in China.

Apple shares jumped 6.1% to close at 128.79 on the stock market today, after the company posted better-than-expected December quarter earnings.

Qualcomm finished the day down 0.5% to 53.15. On Tuesday, Qualcomm stock touched a more than six-month low of 52.83.
title: Qualcomm Lawsuit Was 'Last Resort,' Apple CEO Says
